sentences: Mark Nelson Chesnutt (born September 6, 1963) is an American country music singer and songwriter.
section: N/A

sentences: Between 1990 and 1999, he had his greatest chart success recording for Universal Music Group Nashville's MCA and Decca branches, with a total of eight albums between those two labels.
section: N/A

sentences: During this timespan, Chesnutt also charted twenty top-ten hits on the Billboard Hot Country Songs charts, of which eight reached number one: "Brother Jukebox", "I'll Think of Something", "It Sure Is Monday", "Almost Goodbye", "I Just Wanted You to Know", "Gonna Get a Life", "It's a Little Too Late", and a cover of Aerosmith's "I Don't Want to Miss a Thing".
section: N/A

sentences: His first three albums for MCA (Too Cold at Home, Longnecks & Short Stories, and Almost Goodbye) along with a 1996 Greatest Hits package issued on Decca are all certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA); 1994's What a Way to Live, also issued on Decca, is certified gold.
section: N/A

sentences: After a self-titled album in 2002 on Columbia Records, Chesnutt has continued to record predominantly on independent labels.
section: N/A

sentences: Chesnutt is known for his neotraditionalist country and honky-tonk influences, with frequent stylistic comparisons to George Jones.
section: N/A

sentences: He has recorded several cover songs as both singles and album cuts, including covers of Hank Williams Jr., John Anderson, Don Gibson, Conway Twitty, and Charlie Rich.
section: N/A

sentences: Artists with whom he has collaborated include Jones, Tracy Byrd, Vince Gill, and Alison Krauss.
section: N/A

sentences: Mark Wright produced all but one of his albums released in the 1990s, while his work since 2005 has been produced by Jimmy Ritchey.
section: N/A

sentences: Chesnutt has also won two awards from the Country Music Association: the Horizon Award (now known as Best New Artist) and Vocal Event of the Year, both in 1993.
section: N/A
== Biography ==

sentences: Biography ==
section: == Biography ==

sentences: Mark Nelson Chesnutt was born on September 6, 1963, in Beaumont, Texas.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: He drew musical influence from his father,  Bob Chesnutt, who was a singer and record collector.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: Chesnutt first played drums as a child after receiving a drum kit as a Christmas gift, but at his father's persuasion, he stopped playing drums and chose to focus on singing instead.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: He dropped out of school in the eleventh grade to begin playing in clubs around southeast Texas.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: When he turned 17, his father began to take him to Nashville, Tennessee, to begin recording.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: For the next ten years, he began to record on small regional labels while he was the house band for local Beaumont nightclub Cutters.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: By the late 1980s, he had released eight singles, which would later be released together as an album titled Doing My Country Thing.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: Record producer Tony Brown heard one of Chesnutt's independent releases, and recommended him to Mark Wright, a songwriter, session musician, and record producer who helped Chesnutt sign with the Nashville branch of MCA Records in 1990.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: The same year, Bob Chesnutt died of a heart attack.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: I Wonder Do You Think of Me.

section: == Musical career == | === Longnecks & Short Stories ===

== Musical career == | === Outlaw ===

sentences: In 2010, Chesnutt announced the release of his next studio album, Outlaw.
section: == Musical career == | === Outlaw ===

sentences: The album includes covers of songs by outlaw country artists, including Waylon Jennings, Willie Nelson, Hank Williams Jr., Kris Kristofferson, Billy Joe Shaver, David Allan Coe, and Jerry Jeff Walker.
section: == Musical career == | === Outlaw ===

sentences: According to Chesnutt, he was presented the idea by record producer Pete Anderson, best known for his work with Dwight Yoakam, when Saguaro Road Records was seeking an artist to perform a covers album.
section: == Musical career == | === Outlaw ===

sentences: The two recorded the album at Anderson's studio in Burbank, California, in only two days.
section: == Musical career == | === Outlaw ===

sentences: To support the album, he toured with Tracy Lawrence and Richie McDonald (of Lonestar) on the Country Rat Pack Tour.
section: == Musical career == | === Outlaw ===

sentences: Thom Jurek referred to the album as "a no-frills, solid, lean, mean, rocking, emotionally sincere tribute to the outlaw generation, which is, in many ways, an extension of Chesnutt's own persona."
section: == Musical career == | === Outlaw ===

sentences: In 2013, George Jones invited Chesnutt to be his opener on the last show of his farewell tour at Bridgestone Arena in Nashville, Tennessee.
section: == Musical career == | === Live From The Big D, Greatest Hits II, and Tradition Lives ===

sentences: However, Jones died before the show could take place, so Chesnutt and other artists held a tribute show in Jones's honor instead.

== Additional contributions ==

sentences: Additional contributions ==
section: == Additional contributions ==

sentences: In 1993, Chesnutt was featured in an ad campaign for Frito-Lay where he sang their tagline "I know what I like
section: == Additional contributions ==

sentences: and I like Fritos."
section: == Additional contributions ==

sentences: In 1994, he contributed three cover songs to multi-artist compilation albums.
section: == Additional contributions ==

sentences: These were Merle Haggard's "Goodbye Comes Hard for Me", recorded for the AIDS benefit album Red Hot + Country; Keith Whitley's "I Never Go Around Mirrors (I've Got a Heartache to Hide)" to Keith Whitley: A Tribute Album; and "Good Ones and Bad Ones", a duet with George Jones on the latter's 1994 duets album The Bradley Barn Sessions.
section: == Additional contributions ==

sentences: In 1996, the radio station WKIS in Boca Raton, Florida, compiled a Christmas album titled A Country Christmas from WKIS 99.9, to which Chesnutt contributed a recording of the Christmas carol "What Child Is This?"
section: == Additional contributions ==

sentences: His version made the Hot Country Songs charts that same year due to seasonal airplay.
section: == Additional contributions ==
== Musical style and influences ==

sentences: Musical style and influences ==
section: == Musical style and influences ==

sentences: Chesnutt's musical style draws mainly from honky-tonk and neotraditional country.
section: == Musical style and influences ==

sentences: Due to both singers hailing from Beaumont, Chesnutt was frequently compared stylistically to George Jones.
section: == Musical style and influences ==

sentences: Jack Hurst of the Chicago Tribune wrote that he was "a throwback to the inwardly-tough, just-do-it kind of country star they were making back when they minted George Jones, who preceded Chesnutt out of the rough-and-tumble East Texas honky-tonks 40 years ago."
section: == Musical style and influences ==

sentences: Nash described Chesnutt's vocal style by saying that he "has a comely, smooth baritone and a supple way of moving through his vocal range", and a "friendly foghorn" with "earnestness".
section: == Musical style and influences ==

sentences: Rick Mitchell, writing in The Encyclopedia of Country Music, described Chesnutt as "arguably the strongest pure-country voice to come out of Southeastern Texas since George Jones", and an uncredited review in People said that Chesnutt "has a natural, George Jonesian sob and enough machismo to get away with going falsetto when he wants."
section: == Musical style and influences ==

sentences: Chesnutt has cited Merle Haggard, Hank Williams, and Elvis Presley as major influences of his.
section: == Musical style and influences ==

sentences: Mitchell also noted that Chesnutt was able to have success with both ballads and uptempo material such as "Bubba Shot the Jukebox" and "Old Flames Have New Names", as well as the strong presence of cover songs from the 1950s and 1960s.
section: == Musical style and influences ==

sentences: Some of his songs, such as "It Sure Is Monday" and "Gonna Get a Life", have featured influences of Cajun music through prominent use of fiddle and accordion.
section: == Musical style and influences ==

sentences: Chesnutt's musical persona placed a greater emphasis on song quality over physical attractiveness, compared to the move toward young and attractive males that prevailed in country music in the 1990s.
section: == Musical style and influences ==

sentences: Nash stated that he "distanced himself from the pack with an identifiable baritone and a focus on music over image", and Barry Gilbert of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch similarly stated that he "put the music and his warm, classic-country voice before the image."
section: == Musical style and influences ==

sentences: Chesnutt stated in a 1996 interview that "I would rather play honky-tonks the rest of my life for $500 a week than be something I'm not."
section: == Musical style and influences ==

sentences: He noted that during his latter years at Decca and MCA, he was constantly pressured by label heads to record more mainstream-friendly country pop instead of the traditional sounds of his earlier albums, due to the genre's shift away from neotraditional country having a negative impact on his album sales.
section: == Musical style and influences ==

sentences: He also said that some of the tracks on Savin' the Honky Tonk were songs that the major labels had rejected, and that he would "rather sell 100,000 albums [of traditional country] than 6 million of some crap that I wasn't happy with."
section: == Musical style and influences ==
== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Chesnutt has been married to the former Tracie Motley since 1992.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: The two met in a bar, and according to Chesnutt, "She came out there with a guy she was with at the time, and I took her away from him".
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: The couple have three sons: Waylon, Casey, and Cameron.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Waylon was named after Waylon Jennings, who jokingly suggested during the recording sessions for their cover of "Rainy Day Woman" that the then-pregnant Tracie name their child after him.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Although Jennings later stated that the suggestion was a joke, Chesnutt decided to choose the name anyway.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: In late 1995, following Waylon Chesnutt's birth, Tracie typically stayed home at the couple's house in Jasper, Texas, while also working as an artist.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: The birth of his sons also caused Chesnutt to tour less frequently by the end of the 1990s, as he wanted to be able to spend more time with his family.
section: == Personal life ==
